DIV1.P: THE School for LOVERS, A COMEDY.
As it is Acted at the THEATRE ROYAL in Drury-Lane.
By WILLIAM WHITEHEAD, Esq POET LAUREAT.
LONDON: Printed for R. and J. DODSLEY in Pall-mall; and Sold by J. HINXMAN, in Pater-noster-row.

DIV1.HEAD: ADVERTISEMENT.
DIV1.P: THE following Comedy is formed on a plan of Monsieur de Fontenelle's, never intended for the stage, and printed in the eighth volume of his works, under the title of Le Testament.

The scene of that piece is laid in Greece, and the embarrassing circumstances depend on some peculiarities in the customs of that coun∣try. Slaves likewise, as is usual in the Grecian Comedy, act as confidantes to the principal personages. The Author, therefore, hopes he may be excused for having made the story English, and his own; for having introduced a new character, and endeavoured to heighten those he found already sketched out. The delicacy of the sentiments in Philonoe and Eudamidas, he has inviolably adhered to, wherever he could insert them properly, in his Caelia and Sir John Dorilant; and would willingly flatter himself, that he has made great and not contemptible additions to their characters, as well as to the others.
Those who will give themselves the trouble to read both pieces, will see where the Author is, or is not indebted to that elegant French Writer.
TO THE MEMORY OF MONSIEUR DE FONTENELLE, THIS COMEDY IS INSCRIBED BY A LOVER OF SIMPLICITY,

DIV1.HEAD: PROLOGUE. As it was intended to have been SPOKEN.

LG.L: SUCCESS makes people vain.—The maxim's true,
We all confess it — and not over new.
The veriest clown who stumps along the streets,
And doffs his hat to each grave cit he meets,
Some twelvemonths hence, bedaub'd with livery lace,
Shall thrust his saucy flambeau in your face.
Not so our Bard: tho' twice your kind applause
Has, on this fickle spot, espous'd his cause:
He owns, with gratitude, th' obliging debt;
Has twice been favour'd, and is modest yet.
Plain Tragedy, his first adventurous care,
Spoke to your hearts, and found an echo there,
Plain Comedy to-night, with strokes refin'd,
Would catch the coyest features of the mind:
Would play politely with your hopes and fears,
And sometimes smiles provoke, and sometimes tears,
Your giant wits, like those of old, may climb
Olympus high, and step o'er space and time;
May stride with seven-leagu'd boots, from shore to shore,
And, nobly by transgressing, charm you more.
Alas! our Author dares not laugh at schools,
Plain sense confines his humbler Muse to rules.
Form'd on the classic scale his structures rise,
He shifts no scenes to dazzle and surprize.
In one poor garden's solitary grove,
Like the primaeval pair, his lovers rove.
And in due time will each transaction pass,
— Unless some hasty critic shakes the glass.

DIV1.HEAD: PROLOGUE. As it is spoken by Mr. GARRICK.

LG.L: SUCCESS makes people vain.—The maxim's true.—
We all confess it— and not over new.
The veriest clown, who stumps along the streets,
And doffs his hat to each grave cit he meets,
Some twelvemonths hence, bedaub'd with livery lace,
Shall thrust his saucy flambeau in your face.
Not so our Bard—though twice your kind applause
Has, on this fickle spot, espous'd his cause:
He owns, with gratitude, th' obliging debt;
Has twice been favour'd, and is modest yet.
Your giant wits, like those of old, may climb
Olympus high, and step o'er space and time;
May stride, with seven-leagu'd boots, from shore to shore,
And, nobly by transgressing, charm ye more.
Alas! our Author dares not laugh at schools —
Plain sense confines his humbler Muse to rules:
He shifts no scenes—But here I stop'd him short —
Not change your scenes? said I, — I'm sorry for't:
My constant friends above, around, below,
Have English tastes, and love both change and show▪
Without such aids, even Shakespear would be flat —
Our crouded Pantomimes are proofs of that.
What eager transport stares from every eye,
When pullies rattle, and our Genii fly!
When tin cascades like falling waters gleam:
Or through the canvas—bursts the real stream:
While thirsty Islington laments in vain
Half her New-River roll'd to Drury-Lane.
Lord, Sir, said I, for gallery, boxes, pit,
I'll back my Harlequin against your wit—
Yet still the Author, anxious for his play,
Shook his wise head—What will the critics say?
As usual, Sir—abuse you all they can!—
And what the ladies—He's a charming man!
A charming piece!—One scarce knows what it means;
But that's no matter—where there's such sweet scenes!
Still he persists—and let him—entre nous—
I know your tastes, and will indulge 'em too.
Change you shall have; so set your hearts at ease:
Write as he will, we'll act it as you please.

DIV1.HEAD: PERSONS Represented.

LIST.ITEM: Sir JOHN DORILANT, a Man of nice Honour, Guardian to Caelia, Mr. GARRICK.
MODELY, Men of the Town, Mr. PALMER.
BELMOUR, Men of the Town, Mr. OBRIEN.
An old Steward to Sir John Dorilant, Mr. CASTLE.
Footman to Sir John Dorilant, Mr. FOX.
Lady BEVERLEY, a Widow Lady, Mother to Caelia, Mrs. CLIVE.
CAELIA, Daughter to Lady Beverley, and Ward to Sir John, Mrs. CIBBER.
ARAMINTA, Sister to Sir John Do∣rilant, Mrs. YATES.

DIV1.P: SCENE a Garden belonging to Sir John Dorilant's House in the Country, with an Arbour, Garden Chairs, &c.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT I.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter ARAMINTA with an affected Careless∣ness, and knotting, MODELY following.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: BUT madam!

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: But Sir! what can possibly have alarmed you thus? You see me quite unconcerned. I only tell you in a plain simple narrative manner — (this plaguy thread) — and merely by way of conver∣sation, that you are in love with Caelia; and where is the mighty harm in all this?

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P:
The harm in it, madam! have I not told you a
thousand and a thousand times that you were the only woman who could possibly make me happy?

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Why aye, to be sure you have, and sworn a thousand and a thousand oaths to confirm that as∣sertion.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: And am not I here now expressly to marry you?

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Why that too is true—but—you are in love with Caelia.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Bless me, madam, what can I say to you? If it had not been for my attendance upon you, I had never known Caelia or her mother either, though they are both my relations. The mother has since indeed put some kind of confidence in me; she is a widow you know—

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: And wants consolation! The poor orphan too her daughter! Well, charity is an excellent virtue. I never considered it in that light before. You are vastly charitable, Mr. Modely.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: It is impossible to talk with you.—If you will not do me justice, do it to yourself at least. Is there any comparison betwixt you and Caelia? Could any man of sense hesitate a moment? She has yet no character. One does not know what she is, or what she will be; a chit, a green girl of fourteen or fifteen.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Seventeen at least.—(I cannot undo this knot.)—

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P:
Well, let her be seventeen. Would any man of
judgment attach himself to a girl of that age? O' my soul, if one was to make love to her, she would hardly understand what one meant.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Girls are not quite so ignorant as you may ima∣gine, Mr. Modely; Caelia will understand you, take my word for it, and does understand you. As to your men of judgment and sense, here is my brother now; I take him to be full as reasonable as yourself, and somewhat older; and yet with all his philosophy, he has brought himself to a de∣termination at last, to fulfill the father's will, and marry this green girl. I am sorry to tell you so, Mr. Modely, but he will certainly marry her.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Let him marry her. I should perhaps do it my∣self, if I was in his place. He was an intimate friend of her father's. She is a great fortune, and was given to him by will. But do you imagine, my dear Araminta, that if he was left to his own choice, without any bias, he would not rather have a woman nearer his own years? He might al∣most be her father.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: That is true. But you will find it difficult to persuade me, that youth in a woman is so insur∣mountable an objection. I fancy, Mr. Modely, it may be got over. Suppose I leave you to think of it.—(I cannot get this right.)— Going.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Stay, dear Araminta, why will you plague me thus? Your own charms, my earnestness, might prove to you —

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: I tell you I don't want proofs.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Well, well, you shall have none then. But give me leave to hope, since you have done me the honour to be a little uneasy on my account —

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Uneasy!—I uneasy!— What does the man mean? I was a little concerned indeed to give you uneasiness by informing you of my brother's in∣tended marriage with Caelia. But—(this shuttle bends so abominably.)

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Thou perplexing tyrant! Nay, you shall not go.—May I continue to adore you! you must not forbid me that.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: For my part I neither command nor forbid any thing. Only this I would have you remember, I have quick eyes. Your servant.—(I wish this knotting had never come in fashion.)

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Quick eyes indeed! I thought my cunning here had been a master piece. The girl cannot have told sure! and the mother is entirely on my side. They certainly were those inquisitive eyes she speaks of, which have found out this secret. Well, I must be more cautious for the future, and act the lover to Araminta ten times stronger than ever. One would not give her up till one was sure of suc∣ceeding in the other place.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter BELMOUR from behind with a Book in his Hand.

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! well said Modely!

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY
SP.P: Belmour! how the duce came you here?

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: How came I here? — How came you here— if you come to that? A man can't retire from the noise and bustle of the world, to admire the beauties of the spring, and read pastoral in an arbour, but impertinent lovers must disturb his meditations.— Thou art the errantest hypocrite, Modely —

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Hypocrite!—My dear friend, we men of gal∣lantry must be so.—But have a care, we may have other listeners for aught I know, who may not be so proper for confidantes. Looking about.

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: You may be easy on that head. We have the garden to ourselves. The widow and her daughter are just gone in, and Sir John is busy with his steward.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: The widow, and her daughter! Why, were they in the garden?

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: They just came into it, but upon seeing you and Araminta together, they turned back again.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: On seeing me and Araminta? I hope I have no jealousies there too. However I am glad Caelia knows I am in the garden, because it may probably induce her to fall in my way, by chance you know, and give me an opportunity of talking to her.

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: Do you think she likes you?

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: She does not know what she does.

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: Do you like her?

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Why faith, I think I do.

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: Why then do you pursue your affair with Ara∣minta? and not find some honourable means of breaking off with her?

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: That might not be quite so expedient. I think Araminta the finest woman, and Caelia the prettiest girl I know. Now they are both good fortunes, and one of them I am resolved to have, but which —

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: Your great wisdom has not yet determined. Thou art undoubtedly the vainest fellow living.— I thought you brought me down here now to your wedding?

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: 'Egad I thought so too, but this plaguy little rustic has disconcerted all my schemes. Sir John, you know, by her father's will, may marry her if he pleases, and she forfeits her estate if she marries any one else. Now I am contriving to bring it about, that I may get her, and her fortune too.

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: A very likely business, truly. So you modestly expect that Sir John Dorilant should give up his mistress, and then throw her fortune into the bat∣gain, as an additional reward to the obliging man who has seduced her from him.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Hum! why I don't expect quite that. But you know, Belmour, he is a man of honour, and would not force her inclinations tho' he loved her to dis∣traction. —Come, come, he is quite a different creature from what you and I are.

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: Speak for yourself, good Sir; yet why should you imagine that her inclinations are not as likely to fix upon him as you? He has a good person, and is scarce older than yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: That shews your ignorance; I am ten years younger than he is. My dress and the company I keep, give a youth and vivacity to me, which he must always want. An't I a man of the town? O that town, Belmour! Could I but have met these ladies there, I had done the business.

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: Were they never there?

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Never.—Sir Harry Beverley, the father of this girl, lived always in the country, and divided his time between his books and his hounds. His wife and daughter seldom mixed with people of their own rank, but at a horse-race, or a rural visit. And see the effects! The girl, tho' she is naturally genteel, has an air of simplicity.

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: But does not want sense.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P:
No, no!—She has a devilish deal of that kind of sense, which is acquired by early reading. I have heard her talk occasionally, like a queen in a tragedy, or at least like a sentimental lady in a comedy,
much above your misses of thirty in town, I assure you.—As to the mother—But she is a charac∣ter, and explains herself.

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: Yes, yes, I have read her. But pray how came it to pass, that the father, who was of a different way of thinking in regard to party, should have left Sir John guardian to his daughter, with the addi∣tional clause too, of her being obliged to marry him.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Why that is somewhat surprizing. But the truth of the case was, they were thoroughly acquainted, and each considered party as the foible of the other. Sir Harry thought a good husband his daughter's best security for happiness, and he knew it was im∣possible Sir John Dorilant should prove a bad one.

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: And yet this prospect of happiness would you destroy.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: No, no; I only see farther than Sir Harry did, and would increase that happiness, by giving her a better husband.

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: O! your humble servant, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Besides, the mother is entirely in my interest, and by the by has a hankering after Sir John herself. He is a sober man, and should have a woman of discretion for his wife, not a hoydening girl.— 'Egad, Belmour, suppose you attacked the widow? The woman is young enough, and has an excellent jointure.

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: And so became your father-in-law.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: You will have an admirable opportunity to∣night; we are to have the fiddles you know, and you may dance with her.
When musick softens, and when dancing fires! Eh! Belmour!

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: You are vastly kind to Sir John, and would ease him I find of both his mistresses. But suppose this man of honour should be fool enough to resign his mistress, may not another kind of honour oblige him to run you through the body for deserting his sister?

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Why faith, it may. However, it is not the first duel I have fought on such an occasion, so I am his man. Not that it is impossible but he may have scruples there too.

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: You don't think him a coward?

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: I know he is not. But your reasoning men have strange distinctions. They are quite different crea∣tures, as I told you, from you and I.

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: You are pleased to compliment. But suppose now, as irrational as you think me, I should find out a means to make this whole affair easy to you?

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: How do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: Not by attacking the widow, but by making my addresses in good earnest to Araminta.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: I forbid that absolutely.

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: What, do you think it possible I should suc∣ceed after the accomplished Mr. Modely?

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Why faith between you and I, I think not, but I don't chuse to hazard it.

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: Then you love her still?

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: I confess it.

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: And it is nothing upon earth but that insati∣able vanity of yours, with a little tincture of ava∣rice, that leads you a gadding thus?

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: I plead guilty. But be it as it will, I am deter∣mined to pursue my point. And see where the little rogue comes most opportunely. I told you she would be here. Go, go, Belmour, you must not listen to all my love scenes. Exit Belmour. Now for a serious face, a little upon the tragic; young girls are mighty fond of despairing lovers.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA
SP.P: Mr. Modely!—are you here?—I am come to meet my mama—I did not think to find you here.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Are you sorry to find me here, madam?

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: Why should I be sorry, Mr. Modely?

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: May I hope you are pleased with it?

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: I have no dislike to company.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: But is all company alike? Surely one would chuse one's companions. Would it have been the same thing to you, if you had met Sir John Dorilant here?

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: I should be very ungrateful if I did not like Sir John Dorilant's company. I am sure I have all the obligations in the world to him, and so had my poor papa. Sighing.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Whatever were your papa's obligations, his gratitude I am sure was unbounded.—O that I had been his friend!

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: Why should you wish that, Mr. Modely? — You would have had a great loss in him.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: I believe I should. But I might likewise have had a consolation for that loss, which would have contained in it all earthly happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: I don't understand you.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: He might have left his Caelia to me.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: Dear, how you talk!

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Talk, madam! —O I could talk for ever, would you but listen to my heart's soft language, nor cruelly affect to disbelieve when I declare I love you.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: Love me, Mr. Modely?—Are not you in love with Araminta?

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: I once thought I was.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: And do lovers ever change?

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Not those who feel a real passion. But there are false alarms in love, which the unpractised heart sometimes mistakes for true ones.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: And were yours such for Araminta?

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Alas, I feel they were. (Looking earnestly at her.)

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: You don't intend to marry her then, I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Do you hope I should not marry her?

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: To be sure I do. I would not have the poor lady deceived, and I would willingly have a better opinion of Mr. Modely than to believe him ca∣pable of making false protestations.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: To you he never could.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: To me?—I am out of the question.—But I am sorry for Araminta, for I believe she loves you.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: If you can pity those who love in vain, why am not I an object of compassion?

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P:
Dear Mr. Modely, why will you talk thus? My hand, you know, is destined to Sir John Do∣rilant,
and my duty there does not even permit me to think of other lovers.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Happy, happy man! Yet give me leave to ask one question, madam.—I dread to do it, tho' my last glimpse of happiness depends upon your answer.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: What question?—Nay, pray speak, I intreat it of you.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Then tell me, lovely Caelia, sincerely tell me, were your choice left free, and did it depend upon you only to determine who should be the master of your affections, might I expect one favourable thought?

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA
SP.P: It—it does not depend upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: I know it does not, but if it did?

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: Come, come, Mr. Modely, I cannot talk upon this subject. Impossibilities are impossibilities. — But I hope you will acquaint Araminta instantly with this change in your inclinations.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: I would do it, but I dare not.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: You should break it first to Sir John.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: My difficulty does not lie in the breaking it; but if I confess my passion at an end, I must no longer expect admittance into this family, and I could still wish to talk to Caelia as a friend.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: Indeed, Mr. Modely, I should be loth myself to lose your acquaintance; but — O here comes my mama, she may put you in a method.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: In any method, my dear, which decency and reserve will permit. Your servant, cousin Modely. What, you are talking strangely to this girl now?— O you men!

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Your ladyship knows the sincerity of my passion here.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA
SP.P: Knows your sincerity?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Well, well, what signifies what I know? —You was mentioning some method I was to put you in.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: Mr. Modely, madam, has been confessing to me that he no longer loves Araminta.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Hum!—why such things may happen, child. We are not all able to govern our affections. But I hope if he breaks off with her, he will do it with decency.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: That, madam, is the difficulty.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: What!—Is it a difficulty to be decent? Fie, fie, Mr. Modely.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Far be it from me even to think so, madam, before a person of your ladyship's reserved beha∣viour. But considering how far I have gone in the affair—

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Well, well, if that be all, I may perhaps help you out, and break it to Sir John myself.—Not that I approve of roving affections I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: You bind me ever to you.—But there is ano∣ther cause which you alone can promote, and on which my eternal happiness—

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Leave us—leave us, cousin Modely. I must not hear you talk in this extravagant manner.— [Pushing him towards the scene, and then aside to him.] — I shall bring it about better in your absence. Go, go, man, go. Exit Modely. A pretty kind of a fellow really.—Now Caelia, come nearer, child: I have something of impor∣tance to say to you.—What do you think of that gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: Of Mr. Modely, madam?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Ay Mr. Modely, my cousin Modely.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: Think of him, madam?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Ay, think of him, child; you are old enough to think sure after the education I have given you. Well, what answer do you make?

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: I really don't understand your Ladyship's ques∣tion.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Not understand me, child? Why I ask you how you like Mr. Modely? What should you think of him as a husband.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: Mr. Modely as a husband! Why surely madam, Sir John —

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Fiddle faddle Sir John; Sir John knows better things than to plague himself with a wife in lead∣ing strings.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: Is your ladyship sure of that?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: O ho! would you be glad to have me sure of it?

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: I don't know what I should be glad of. I would not give Sir John a moment's pain to be mistress of the whole world.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: But if it should be brought about without giv∣ing him pain. Hey! Caelia— Patting her cheek with her fan.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: I should be sorry for it.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Hey day!

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: For then he must think lightly of me.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: What does the girl mean? Come, come, I must enter roundly into this affair. Here, here, sit down, and tell me plainly and honestly without equivoca∣tion or reservation, is Modely indifferent to you? Nay, nay,—look me in the face; turn your eyes to∣wards me. One judges greatly by the eyes, espe∣cially in a woman. Your poor papa used to say that my eyes reasoned better than my tongue. — Well, and now tell me without blushing, is Modely indifferent to you?

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: I fear he is not, madam, and it is that which perplexes me.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: How do you feel when you meet him?

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: Fluttered.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Hum! —While you are with him?

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: Fluttered.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Hum! —When you leave him?

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: Fluttered still.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Strong symptoms truly!

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: When Sir John Dorilant talks to me, my heart is softened but not perplexed. My esteem, my gratitude overflows towards him. I consider him as a kinder father, with all the tenderness without the authority.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: But when Mr. Modely talks?

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA
SP.P: My tranquility of mind is gone, I am pleased with hearing what I doubt is flattery, and when he grasps my hand —

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Well, well, I know all that.—Be decent, child. —You need say no more, Mr. Modely is the man. Rising.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: But, dear Madam, there are a thousand obstacles. —I am afraid Sir John loves me; I am sure he esteems me, and I would not forfeit his esteem for the universe. I am certain I can make him an af∣fectionate and an humble wife, and I think I can forget Mr. Modely.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Forget a fiddle! Don't talk to me of forgetting. I order you on your duty not to forget. Mr. Modely is, and shall be the man. You may trust my prudence for bringing it about. I will talk with Sir John instantly.—I know what you are going to say, but I will not hear a word of it. Can you imagine, Caelia, that I shall do any thing but with the utmost decency and decorum?

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: I know you will not, madam; but there are de∣licacies —

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: With which I am unacquainted to be sure, and my daughter must instruct me in them. Pray, Caelia, where did you learn this nicety of sentiments? Who was it that inspired them?

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: But the maxims of the world —

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Are altered, I suppose, since I was of your age. Poor thing, what world hast thou seen? Notwith∣standing your delicacies and your maxims, Sir John perhaps may be wiser than you imagine, and chuse a wife of somewhat more experience.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: May he be happy wherever he chuses.—But dear madam —

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Again? don't make me angry. I will positively not be instructed. Ay, you may well blush.— Nay, no tears—Come, come, Caelia, I forgive you. I had idle delicacies myself once. Lard! I remember when your poor papa —he, he, he— but we have no time for old stories. What would you say now if Sir John himself should propose it, and persuade the match, and yet continue as much your friend as ever, nay become more so, a nearer friend.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: In such a case, madam —

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: I understand you, and will about it instantly. B'ye Caelia; O how its little heart flutters!

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: It does indeed. A nearer friend? I hardly know whether I should wish her success or not — Sir John is so affectionate. Would I had never seen Mr. Modely! —Araminta too! what will she say? — O I see a thousand bad consequences. I must follow her, and prevent them.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT II.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: PRITHEE don't teize me so; I vow, cousin Modely, you are almost as peremptory as my daughter. She truly was teaching me decorum just now, and plaguing me with her delicacies, and her stuff. I tell you Sir John will be in the gar∣den immediately, this is always his hour of walk∣ing: and when he comes, I shall lay the whole affair before him, with all its concatenation of cir∣cumstances, and I warrant you bring it about.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: I have no doubt, madam, of the transcendency of your ladyship's rhetorick; it is on that I entirely rely. But I must beg leave to hint, that Araminta already suspects my passion, and should it be openly declared, would undoubtedly prevail that instant with her brother to forbid me the house.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Why, that might be.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P:
And tho' I told your daughter I did not care how soon it came to an eclaircisment, yet a woman of your ladyship's penetration and knowledge of
the world, must see the necessity of concealing it, at least for a time. I beg pardon for offering what may have even the distant appearance of instruction. But it is Sir John's delicacy which must be princi∣pally alarmed with apprehensions of her disregard for him; and I am sure your ladyship's manner of doing it, will shew him where he might much better place his affections, and with an undoubted prospect of happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Ay, now you talk to the purpose.—But stay, is not that Sir John coming this way?—It is I vow, and Araminta with him. We'll turn down this walk, and reason the affair a little more, and then I will come round the garden upon him.
SP.STAGE: Modely takes her hand to lead her out.
SP.P: You are very gallant, cousin Modely. Exeunt.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter SIR JOHN DORILANT and ARAMINTA.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: What do you drag me into the garden for? We were private enough where we were—and I hate walking.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Forgive me, my dear sister; I am restless every where, my head and heart are full of nothing but this lovely girl.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P:
My dear, dear brother, you are enough to spoil any woman in the universe. I tell you again and again, the girl is a good girl, an excellent girl, and will make an admirable wife. You may trust one woman in her commendations of another; we are
not apt to be too favourable in our judgments, especially when there is beauty in the case.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: You charm me when you talk thus. If she is really all this, how happy must the man be who can engage her affections. But alas! Araminta, in every thing which regards me, it is duty, not love, which actuates her behaviour. She steals away my very soul by her attentions, but never once expresses that heart-felt tenderness, those sym∣pathetic feelings.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Ha—ha — ha!—O my stars!— Sympathetic feelings!—Why, would you have a girl of her age have those sympathetic feelings, as you call them! If she had, take my word for it, she would coquet it with half the fellows in town before she had been married a twelvemonth. Besides, Sir John, you don't consider that you was her father's friend; she has been accustomed from her infancy to respect you in that light; and our fathers friends, you know, are always old people, grey beards, philoso∣phers, enemies to youth, and the destruction of gayety.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: But I was never such.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: You may imagine so; but you always had a grave turn. I hated you once myself.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Dear Araminta!

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P:
I did as I hope to live; for many a time has your aversion to dancing hindered me from having a fiddle.—By the by, remember we are to have the fiddles
to-night.—But let that pass: As the case now stands, if I was not already so near akin to you, you have the temper in the world which I should chuse in a husband.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN
SP.P: That is obliging, however.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Not so very obliging perhaps neither. It would be merely for my own sake, for then would I have the appearance of the most obedient sympathetic wife in the universe, and yet be as despotic in my govern∣ment as an eastern monarch. And when I grew tired, as I probably should do, of a want of contradiction, why, I should find an easy remedy for that too— I could break your heart in about a month.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Don't trifle with me, 'tis your serious advice I want; give it me honestly as a friend, and ten∣derly as a sister.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Why I have done it, fifty times. What can I say more? If you will have it again you must. This then it is in plain terms.—But you are sure you are heartily in love with her?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Pshaw!

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Well then, that we will take for granted; and now you want to know what is right and proper for you to do in the case. Why, was I in your place, I should make but short work with it. She knows the circumstances of her father's will, therefore, would I go immediately to her, tell her how my heart stood inclined, and hope she had no objections to comply, with what it is not in her power to refuse.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: You would not have me talk thus abruptly to her?

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Indeed I would. It will save a world of trouble. She will blush perhaps at first, and look a little aukward, (and by the by so will you too); but if she is the girl I take her for, after a little irresolute gesture, and about five minutes conversation, she will drop you a curtesy with the demure humility of a Vestal, and tell you it shall be as you and her mama pleases.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: O that it were come to that!

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: And pray what hinders it? Nothing upon earth but your consummate prudence and discretion.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: I cannot think of marrying her, till I am sure she loves me.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Lud, Lud!—why what does that signify? If she consents is not that enough?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Her gratitude may induce her to consent, rather than make me unhappy.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: You would absolutely make a woman mad.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Why, could you think of marrying a man who had no regard for you.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: The case is widely different, my good casuistical brother; and perhaps I could not — unless I was very much in love with him.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: And could you then?

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Yes I could—to tell you the truth I believe I shall.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: What do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: I shall not tell you.—You have business enough of your own upon your hands.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Have you any doubts of Modely?

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: I shall keep them to myself if I have. For you are a wretched counsellor in a love case.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: But dear Araminta—

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: But dear Sir John Dorilant, you may make your∣self perfectly easy, for you shall positively know no∣thing of my affairs. As to your own, if you do not instantly resolve to speak to Caelia, I will go and talk to her myself.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Stay, lady Beverley is coming towards us.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: And has left my swain yonder by himself.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Suppose I break it to her?

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P:
It is not a method which I should advise; but do as you please.—I know that horrid woman's sen∣timents very exactly, and I shall be glad to have her teized a little (Aside.) — I'll give you an op∣portunity
by leaving you; and so adieu, my dear sentimental brother!
We'll change partners if you please, madam — To lady Beverley as she enters. —And then exit to Modely.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY BEVERLEY.
SP.P: Poor mistaken creature! how fond the thing is!—
Your servant, Sir John.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Your ladyship's most obedient. — [After some irresolute gesture on both sides — lady Beverley speaks.]

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: I— I— have wanted an opportunity of speaking to you, Sir John, a great while.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: And I, madam, have long had an affair of conse∣quence to propose to your ladyship.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: An affair of consequence to me! — O Lud— you will please to speak, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN
SP.P: Not till I have heard your ladyship's com∣mands.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: What, must women speak first? Fie, Sir John— (looking languishingly) — Well then, the matter in short is this, I have been long thinking how to dis∣pose of my girl properly. She is grown a woman you see, and tho' I who am her mother say it, has her allurements.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Uncommon ones indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Now I would willingly consult with you how to get her well married, before she is tainted with the indecorums of the world.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: It was the very subject which I proposed speak∣ing to you upon.— I am sorry to put your lady∣ship in mind of a near and dear loss—But you re∣member Sir Harry's will.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Yes, yes, I remember it very well. Poor man! it was undoubtedly the only weak thing he was ever guilty of.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: I say, Sir, John we must pardon the sailings of our deceased friends. Indeed his affection for his child excuses it.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Excuses it!

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Yes indeed does it. His fondness for her might naturally make him wish to place her with a person of your known excellence of character; for my own part, had I died, I should have wished it myself.—I don't believe you have your equal in the world.— Nay, dear Sir John, 'tis no compliment.—This I say might make him not attend to the impropriety of the thing, and the reluctance a gentleman of your good sense and judgment must undoubtedly have to accede to so unsuitable a treaty. Especially as he could not but know there were women of discre∣tion in the world, who would be proud of an al∣liance where the prospect of felicity, was so inviting and unquestionable.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN, who had appeared uneasy all the time she was speaking.
SP.P: What women, madam? I know of none.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Sir John!—That is not quite so complaisant me∣thinks—to our sex, I mean.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: I beg your pardon, madam; I hardly know what I say. Your ladyship has disconcerted every thing I was going to propose to you.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Bless me, Sir John!—I disconcerted every thing? How pray? I have been only talking to you in an open friendly manner, with regard to my daughter, our daughter indeed I might call her, for you have been a father to her. The girl herself always speaks of you as such.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Speaks of me as a father?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Why, more unlikely things have happened, Sir John.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Than what, madam?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Dear Sir John!—You put such peremptory ques∣tions, you might easily understand what one meant methinks.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: I find, madam, I must speak plain at once.— Know then, my heart, my soul, my every thought of happiness is fixed upon that lovely girl.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P:
O astonishing! Well, miracles are not ceased, that's certain. But every body, they say, must do a foolish
thing once in their lives.—And can you really and seriously think of putting Sir Harry's will in execution?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Would I could!

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: To be sure the girl has a fine fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Fortune! I despise it. I would give it with all my soul to any one who could engage me her af∣fections.—Fortune! dirt.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: I am thunderstruck! —

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: O madam, tell me, sincerely tell me, what me∣thod can I possibly pursue to make her think fa∣vourably of me! You know her inmost soul, you know the tender moments of address, the easy avenues to her unpractised heart. Be kind, and point them out. Grasping her hand.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: I vow, Sir John, I don't know what to say to you. — Let go my hand. — You talked of my disconcerting you just now, I am sure you dis∣concert me with a witness.— (Aside.) I did not think the man had so much rapture in him. He squeezed my hand with such an emphasis! I may gain him perhaps at last.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Why will you not speak, madam? Can you see me on the brink of desperation, and not lend a friend∣ly hand to my assistance?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P:
I have it.— (Aside.) —Alas, Sir John, what
signifies what I can do! Can I answer for the incli∣nations of a giddy girl?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: You know she is not such; her innocent mind is yet untainted with the follies of her sex. And if a life devoted to her service, without a wish but what regards her happiness, can win her to be mine —

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Why that might go a great way with an unpre∣judiced mind. But when a first passion has taken place.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: What do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: To tell you the truth, I am afraid the girl is not so untainted as you imagine.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: You distract me. — How—when — whom can she have seen?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Undoubtedly there is a man.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Tell me who, that I may — No, that I may give her to him, and make her happy whatever be∣comes of me.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: That is generous indeed.—So — so. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: But 'tis impossible. I have observed all her mo∣tions, all her attentions, with a lover's eye incapa∣ble of erring.—Yet stay— has any body written to her?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: There are no occasion for letters, when people are in the same house together.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Confusion!

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: I was going to offer some proposals to you, but your strange declaration stopped me short.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: You proposals? —You?—Are you her a better in the affair? — O madam, what un∣pardonable crime have I committed against you, that you should thus conspire my ruin? Have not I always behaved to you like a friend, a brother? — I will not call you ungrateful.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Mercy on us! —The man raves.— How could it possibly enter into my head, or the girl's either, that you had any serious thoughts of marrying her? But I see you are too much discomposed at present, to admit of calm reasoning. So I shall take some other opportunity.—Friend—Brother — Un∣grateful!—Marry come up!— I hope, at least, you will not think of forcing the poor girl's inclinations! Ungrateful indeed! Exit in a passion.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P:
Not for the universe.—Stay, madam.—She is gone.— But it is no matter. I am but little dis∣posed for altercation now. Heigh ho! —Good heaven! can so slight an intercourse have effected all this? — I have scarce ever seen them together. O that I had been born with Belmour's happy ta∣lents of address. — Address!— 'tis absolute ma∣gick, 'tis fascination — Alas! 'tis the rapidity of real passion. — Why did Modely bring him hither to his wedding? Every thing has conspired against me. He brought him, and the delay of the lawyers has kept him here. Had I taken Araminta's advice a poor fortnight ago, it had not been in the power of fate to have undone me. — And yet she might
have seen him afterwards, which would at least have made her duty uneasy to her.—Heigh ho!

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: I tell you, I heard them very loud! and I will see what is the matter. O! here is my brother alone.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: O Araminta!—I am lost beyond redemption.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Dear brother, what can have happened to you?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Mr. Modely, you could not intend it; but you have ruined me.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: I, Sir John!

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: You have brought a friend with you, who has pierced me to the very soul.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Belmour!

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: He has stolen my Caelia's affections from me.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Belmour!

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: This must he a mistake, but I'll humour it. (Aside.) It cannot be, who can have told you so?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Her mother has been this instant with me, to make proposals on the subject.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: For Belmour!

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P:
She did not absolutely mention his name, but I
could not mistake it. For she told me the favoured lover was under the same roof with us.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: I could not have believed it of him.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Nor do I yet.— Looking slyly again at Modely.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: There must certainly be some mistake in it; at the worst, I am sure I can prevail so far with Bel∣mour, as to make him drop his pretensions.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: You cannot make her cease to love him. Sighing.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Time may easily get the better of so young a passion.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Never, never; she is too sincere, too delicately sensible.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Come, come, you must not think so; it is not yet gone so far, but that it may be totally forgotten.— Now for a master-stroke to clench the whole— (Aside.) In the mean time, Sir John, I have the satisfaction of acquainting you, that my affair, with Araminta's leave, draws very near a conclusion. The lawyers have finished their papers, and I only now wait for your perusal of them.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Well said!

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: I ordered the writings to be laid upon your table.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: What does he mean?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P:
Dear Mr. Modely, you shall not wait a moment for me. I will dispatch them instantly. I feel the
want of happiness too severely myself, to postpone it in others. I leave you with my sister; when she names the day, you may depend upon my concur∣rence. Exit Sir John.
SP.STAGE: (MODELY and ARAMINTA look at one ano∣ther for some time, then he speaks.)
SP.P: I hope, madam, you are now convinced of my sincerity.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: I am absolutely struck dumb with your assurance.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: You cannot mean all this.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Why not, madam?

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Why, don't you know that I know—

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: I cannot help a lady's knowledge or imagina∣tions. All I know is, that it is in your power to make me either the happiest or most miserable man in the whole creation.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Well, this is astonishing.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: I am sorry, madam, that any unguarded behavi∣our of mine, any little playful gallantries, should have occasioned surmises, which—

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Serious, as I hope to live.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P:
Is it not enough to make one serious, when the woman one has pursued for years, almost with ado∣ration, is induced by mere appearances to doubt
the honourableness of one's intentions. Have you not heard me this moment apply to your brother, even in the midst of his uneasiness.—I little ex∣pected where the difficulty would lie.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Well, well, poor thing, I won't teize it any lon∣ger; here, there, take my hand.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Duped by Jupiter. — (Aside.) — O my ever∣lasting treasure! And when, and when shall I be happy?

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: It shall depend upon yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: To-morrow, then, my angel, be the day. O Araminta, I cannot speak my transport.—And did you really think that I was in love with Caelia?

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Why, as a proof of my future sincerity, I must confess I did.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: I wonder how you could.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Come, come, there were grounds enough for a woman in love to go upon.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: But you are now perfectly easy?

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Why, yes, I think I am.—But what can my brother mean about Belmour?

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: It is some trick of the widow's.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: I dare say she meant you.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Possibly she might; you know her motives.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Yes, yes, her passion for my brother is pretty no∣torious. But the wretch will be mistaken.—To∣morrow, you say?

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: To-morrow, my adorable.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: It shall be as you please.—But my situation is so terribly aukward, that I must break from you. Adieu! Exit Araminta.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Upon my soul she is a fine woman; and loves me to distraction; and what is still more, I most un∣doubtedly love her.—I have a good mind to take her.—Yet not to have it in my power to suc∣ceed in the other place, would call my parts in question.—No, no; — I must not disparage my parts neither.—In order to be a great character, one should go as near being a rogue as possible. I have a philosopher's opinion on my side in that, and the practice of half the heroes and politicians in Europe.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT III.

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR
SP.P: CAELIA in love with me! Egad the thing is not impossible; my friend Modely may have been a little mistaken. Sir John was very serious when he told me of it; and though I protested to him that I had never made the least advances, he still persisted in his opinion.—The girl must have have told him so herself.—Let me recollect a little. —She is always extremely civil to me; but that indeed she is to every body.—I do not remember any thing particular in her looks; but I shall watch them more narrowly the next time I see her.—She is very handsome; and yet in my opi∣nion, notwithstanding Modely's infidelity, Ara∣minta is much the finer woman.—Suppose— No, that will not do.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: So, so, Mr. Belmour, I imagined I should find you here; this is the lover's corner. We have all had our reveries in it. But why don't you talk louder, man? You ought, at least, to give me my revenge in that. My soliloquies, you know, are easily over-heard.

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: I never designedly over-heard them, Mr. Modely; nor did I make any improper use of the accident.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Grave, very grave, and perfectly moral! And so this is all I am to have for the loss of my mis∣tress.—Heigh ho!

Q.L: Then I must be content to see her bless

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: Your raillery is a little unseasonable, Mr. Mode∣ly; for to speak plainly, I begin to suspect that this is some trick of yours, to dupe me as well as Sir John Dorilant.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Upon my honour, no, if we must be serious: it may be a mistake, but not intended on my side, I can assure you. Come, come, if the girl really likes you, take her. If I should prove the happy man, give me joy, and there's an end of it.

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: I fancy you are used to disappointments in love, they sit so easy upon you. Or rather I should sup∣pose, in this case, you are pretty sure of your ground.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Neither, upon my soul; but a certain Je ne scai quoy, a Gayete de Coeur which carries me above misfortunes: some people call it vanity.

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: And are not absolutely mistaken. But what becomes of Araminta all this while?

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: I shall marry her, I believe, to-morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: Marry her?

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Yes, Sir John is at this very moment looking over the settlements.

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: I don't understand you.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: And yet it is pretty plain, methinks. I tell you I am to be married to-morrow. Was it not time to make sure of one mistress, when you was running away with the other?

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: You know I have no such intentions.—But are you really serious? Have you laid aside your designs upon Caelia?

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Not so, neither.

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: What do you mean then by your marriage with Araminta? Why won't you unriddle this affair to me?

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Because it is at present a riddle to myself, and I expect lady Beverley here every moment to resolve the enigma.

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: Was it a scheme of her's?

SP.SPEAKER: MODLEY.
SP.P: Certainly, and I partly guess it, but will not un∣bosom till I know it fully.—Come, come, with all that gravity of countenance and curiosity, you must leave me instantly; the lady will be here, and the plot unravelled, and then—

SP.SPEAKER: BELMOUR.
SP.P: I shall expect to be satisfied. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! or else you fight me, I suppose. Why, so you may; and so may Sir John Dorilant too, and faith with some colour of reason. But my comfort is, that I have experience on my side, and if I survive the rencounter, I shall be a greater hero than ever amongst the ladies, and be esteemed in all companies as much a man of honour as the best of you.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Dear cousin Modely, I am all over in an agita∣tion; we shall certainly be discovered; that devil Araminta —

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: What of her, madam?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Is now with her brother talking so eagerly— Oh! I saw the villainous changes in her counte∣nance; I would have given the world to have over∣heard their conversation.—Come, come, you must advise me instantly.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Your ladyship must first let me into the secret. I am absolutely in a wood with regard to the whole affair. What is all this of Caelia and Belmour?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Nothing, nothing at all; an errant dilemma of the foolish man's own making, which his imper∣tinent sister will immediately clear up to him, and then all must out.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: But how came Belmour ever to be mentioned in the case?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Dear, dear, he never was mentioned. I must confess that I was so provoked with Sir John's un∣natural behaviour, that I could not help telling him that Caelia had a lover, and in the house too. Your situation with regard to Araminta made him never dream of you, and consequently all his suspicions turned on Belmour.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: But you did not say that that lover had made his addresses to Caelia?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: I don't know what I might say; for he used me like a Turk. But whatever I said I can unsay it again.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Why, if I might venture to advice a person of your lady's sagacity —

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: O ay, with all my heart, cousin Modely. For though I may say it without vanity, that nobody has a more clear apprehension of things when the mental faculty is totally undisturbed; yet, when I am in a trepidation, nobody upon earth can be more glad of advice.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Why, then, madam, to speak with reverence, I should hope your ladyship would see the necessity of keeping me as concealed as possible. It is the young lady's passion, not mine, which must have the principal influence. Sir John Dorilant's pecu∣liarity of temper is such—

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Yes, yes, he has peculiarity enough, that's cer∣tain.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: And it is there, madam, as the weakest part, that our attack will be the surest. If she confesses an inclination for me, not both the Indies, added to her fortune, could induce him to marry her.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: That is honourable, however, cousin Modely. But he is a horrid creature, notwithstanding.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: I grant it, madam; but a failure in an improper pursuit may recal his reason, and, as he does not want understanding, teach him to search for hap∣piness where only it is to be expected.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: He! he! I am so angry with him at present, that I really believe I should refuse him.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Your ladyship must not be too cruel.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Why, I confess it is not in my nature; but— bless me, here they come.—Let us run down this walk directly, for they must not see us to∣gether. Exeunt.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter ARAMINTA and SIR JOHN DORILANT.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P:
Come along, I say, you dragged me into the garden just now, and I will command in my turn. Talk to her you must, and shall. The girl has sense and spirit when she is disengaged from that
horrid mother of her's; and I have told her you wanted her, and in this very spot.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: You cannot feel, Araminta, what you make me suffer. But sooner or later it must come to this, and therefore I will assume a resolution, and be rid of all my doubts at once.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: I tell you, this nonsense about Belmour is merely a phantom of her mother's raising, to sound your intentions, and promote her own.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Thus far is certain, that Belmour disclaims all knowledge of the affair, and with an appearance of sincerity; but even that is doubtful. Besides, they are not his, but her inclinations which give me any concern. It is the heart I require. The life∣less form, beauteous as it is, would only elude my grasp; the shadow of a joy, not the reality.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Dear, dear, that men had but a little common sense; or that one could venture to tell them what one knows of one's own sex! I have a good mind to be honest.—As I live, the girl is coming. —I'll speed her on the way. Courage, brother, Voila! Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: How shall I begin with her?—What ideots are men when they have a real passion! ridiculous, beneath contempt. — [Walks about the stage] —Suppose —I will not suppose; the honest heart shall speak its faithful dictates, and if it fails, — why, let it.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA
SP.P: Araminta tells me, Sir, that you had something to say to me.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: I have, madam.—Come forward, Miss Be∣verley.—Would you chuse to sit.— [They sit down.] — [After some irresolute gesture.] You are not afraid of catching cold?

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: Not in the least, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: I know sitting in the open air has that effect upon some people—but your youth and con∣stitution. — Did my sister say any thing concern∣ing the subject I would speak to you upon?

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: She only told me, Sir, that it was of moment.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: It is of moment, indeed, Caelia.—But you must not think that I am angry.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: Angry, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: I don't mean angry.—I am a little confused; but I shall recover myself presently.— [Rises, and Caelia rises too.] —Nay, pray sit, Miss Beverley. —Whatever I feel myself, I would not disturb you.— [Returns to his seat, then after a pause, goes on.] —The affair I would speak to you upon is this:—You remember your father perfectly?

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: And ever shall.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Indeed he was a good man, Miss Beverley, a virtuous man, and felt tenderly for your happi∣ness. —Those tears become you, and yet, me∣thinks, I would not provoke them. —When he died, he left you to my care.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: Which alone made his loss supportable.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Are you sincere in what you say?

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: I should be ungrateful indeed, if I was not.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN
SP.P: Nay, you are sincerity itself.—O Caelia [Taking her by the hand.] —But I beg your pardon, I am assuming a liberty I have no right to take, till you allow it.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: I see I have alarmed you.—Retire Miss Be∣verley.—I'll speak to you some other time.— [She is going.] —Caelia, Miss Beverley,— pray come back, my dear.—I am afraid my behaviour is rather too abrupt.—Perhaps, too, it may dis∣please you.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: I can be displeased with nothing from you, Sir; and am ready to obey you, be your commands what they will.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Command, Caelia! —that's a hard word.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: I am sorry it offends you.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: You know best, Caelia, whether it ought to of∣fend me—would I could read the sentiments of your heart! Mine are but too apparent.—In short, my dear, you know the purport of your father's will— dare you fulfil it?

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: To the minutest circumstance.—It is my duty.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Ah, Caelia, that word duty destroys the obliga∣tion.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: Sir!—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: I don't know how it is, but I am afraid to ask you the only question, which sincerely answered, could make me happy—or miserable. Half aside.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: Let me beg of you, sir, to ask it freely.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Well then — is your heart your own?

O Caelia, that hesitation confirms my fears. You cannot answer in the affirmative, and have too much humanity for what I feel, to add to my torments. —Good God! — and is it possible, that an acquaint∣ance of a few days, should entirely obliterate the at∣tentive assiduity, the tender anxieties which I have shewn for years!—But I understand it all too well. Mine were the aweful, though heart-felt attentions of a parent; his, the sprightly address of a presum∣ing lover. His easy assurance has won upon your affections, and what I thought my greatest merit, has undone me.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P:
You were so good, sir, a little while ago, to pity
my confusion; pity it now, and whilst I lay my heart open before you, be again that kind, that ge∣nerous friend, which I have always found you.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Go on.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: It is in vain for me to dissemble an ignorance of your meaning, nor would I if I could. I own I have been too much pleased with Mr. Modely's conver∣sation.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Modely's?

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: Let me go on.—His intended marriage with Araminta, gave him a freedom in this family which it was not my business to restrain. His attentions to my mother, and the friendly manner in which he executed some commissions of consequence to her, gave him frequent opportunities of talking to me. I will confess too, that his appearance and his man∣ner struck me. But I was so convinced of his real passion for Araminta, that I never dreamt of the least attachment to me, till—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Till what, when— Modely?—Why, he is to be married to my sister to-morrow or next day.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: I know it was so intended, but his behaviour this morning, and the intercessions of my mother, had, I own, won upon me strangely, and induced me to believe that I only was the object of his pursuits.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: I am thunderstruck! —

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P:
My mother made me clearly perceive that the
completion of his marriage would be an injury to Araminta. She told me too, sir, that you yourself would be my adviser in the affair, and even per∣suad me to accept it.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: O the malicious woman!

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: In that indeed I perceive she greatly erred. And I only mean this as a confession of what is past, and of what is now at an end for ever.—For the fu∣ture, I give myself to your guidance alone, and am what you direct.— Giving her hand to him.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Thou amiable softness! —No, Caelia, how∣ever miserable I may be myself, I will not make you so; it was your heart, not your hand I aspired to. As the former has been seduced from me, it would be an injustice to us both to accept of the latter. As to Mr. Modely, and Lady Beverley, I have not deserved this treachery from them, and they shall both feel my resentment.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: She told me indeed there was a favoured lover, and my suspicions fell very naturally upon Belmour. Nay, even now, nothing but that lovely sincerity— which undoes me—could make me credit this vil∣lainy of Modely.—O Caelia! what a heart have I lost!

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: You cannot, shall not lose it; worthless as it is, 'tis yours, and only yours, my father, guardian, lover, husband! Hangs upon him weeping.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Hey day! what a scene is here! What is the matter with ye both.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: O sister! that angel goodness, that mirror of her sex, has ruined me.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Ruined you! how?

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Nay, I am not the only sufferer, Modely is as false to you, as her mother is to all of us.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: I don't understand you.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: You will too soon. My suspicions of Belmour were all a chimaera; it is your impious Modely who has possession of her heart.—To me she is lost ir∣recoverably. — Going.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Stay, brother.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: I cannot, my soul's too full. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Pray, miss Beverley, what is the meaning of all this?

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: I cannot speak — Throwing herself into a chair.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P:
I'll be hang'd if this fellow Modely has not talk∣ed you into an opinion, that he is in love with you; indeed, my dear, your youth and inexperience may lead you into strange scrapes; and that mother of
yours is enough to turn any girl's head in the uni∣verse. Come, come, unriddle this affair to me.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: Alas! madam▪ all I know is, that the only man I ever did, or ever can esteem, despises me, and, I fear, hates me.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Hates you! he doats upon you to distraction.— But pray, did Modely ever make any serious ad∣dresses to you?

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: Alas! but too often.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: The hypocrite! but I'll be even with him. — And your mother, I suppose, encouraged him? An infamous woman! But I know her drift well enough.—

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Where is my poor girl? I met Sir John Dori∣lant in such a furious way, that he seems to have lost all common civility. What have they done to you, child?

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Done to her? What has your ladyship done to her? I knew your little artifices long ago, but—

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: My artifices! Mrs. Araminta.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P:
Your artifices, lady Beverley; but they are all to no purpose; the girl has too good an understand∣ing to be imposed upon any longer; and your boast∣ed
machinations are as vain and empty in their ef∣fect, as in their contrivance.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: What does the woman mean? But the loss of a lover, I suppose, is an excuse for ill-breeding! Poor creature! if the petulancy of thy temper would let me, I could almost pity thee. The loss of a lover is no agreeable thing; but women at our time of life, Mrs. Araminta, must not expect a lasting pas∣sion.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Scarce any at all I believe, if they go a wooing themselves. For my part, I have had the satisfac∣tion of being sollicited however. And I am afraid my rustic brother never gave your ladyship's sollici∣tations even the slightest encouragement. How was it? Did you find him quite hard-hearted? No bowels of compassion for so accomplished a damsel?

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: Dear madam! dear Araminta!

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Stand away, child. — Desert, madam, is not al∣ways attended with success, nor confidence neither. There are some women so assured of their conquest, as even to disgust a lover on the very day of marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Was my behaviour ever such?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: I really cannot say, Mrs. Araminta; but the world, you know, is censorious enough, when a match is broken off so near its conclusion, as gene∣rally to charge the inconstancy of the lover on some defect in his mistress.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: I defy him to produce any.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: And yet he has certainly left you; Never, ah never to return.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Insolent!

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: Dear Araminta!

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: But your ladyship may be mistaken even in that too. I may find him at his sollicitations again; and if I do —

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: You'll take him.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Take him? —Daggers and poison sooner.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Poor creature!—Come, Caelia, words do but ag∣gravate her misfortune. We only disturb her. You see, my dear, what are the effects of too vio∣lent a passion. It may be a lesson for your future conduct.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Look you, lady Beverley, don't provoke me.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Why, what will you do?

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: For heaven's sake, madam —

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: I fancy, Mrs. Araminta, instead of quarrelling, we had better join forces. If we could but get this girl out of the way, we might both succeed.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: You are a wicked woman.—

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Poor creature! shall I say any thing to my cousin Modely for you? You know I have weight with him.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Yes, madam; you may tell him that his connec∣tions with you, have rendered him ridiculous; and that the revenge of an injured woman is never con∣temptible. Exit Araminta.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.STAGE: (leading off Caelia on the other side.)
SP.P: Poor creature!—Come along, child.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT IV.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN DORILANT, alone.
SP.P: THIS fatal spot, which draws me to it almost involuntarily, must be the scene of another interview.—Thank heaven I have recovered my∣self. Nor shall any misery which I may suffer, much less any prospect of a mean revenge, make me act unbecoming my character.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: Well, brother, I hope you are resolved to marry this girl.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Marry her, my dear Araminta? Can you think it possible, that I should have so preposterous a thought? No, my behaviour shall deserve her, but not over-rule her inclinations. Were I to seize the tender opportunity of her present disposition, the world would ascribe it to her fortune; and I am sure my deceased and valuable friend, however kindly he meant to me in the affair, never intend∣ed that I should make his daughter unhappy.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: But I tell you she loves you; and you must and shall marry her.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Ah sister, you are willing to dispose of her any way. That worthless lover of yours still hangs about your heart, and I have avoided seeing him on your account, as well as Caelia's.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTA.
SP.P: To shew how mistaken you are in all this, I have given him up totally. I despise, and hate him; nay I am upon the brink of a resolution to give myself to another. Sir John shakes his head. I am, I assure you; his friend Mr. Belmour is by no means indifferent on my subject.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: And is this revenge on yourself, a proof of your want of passion for him?—Ah Araminta!—Come, come, my dear, I own I think him unworthy of you, and would resent his usage to the utmost, did not I clearly perceive that it would appear mercenary in myself, and give real pain both to you and Caelia.

SP.SPEAKER: ARAMINTHA.
SP.P: I actually don't know what to say to you.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P:
You had better say nothing. Your spirits at present are too much alarmed.—I have sent for Caelia hither, a short hour may determine the fates of all of us. I know my honourable intentions will give her great uneasiness. But it is my duty which exacts them from me.—You had better take a turn or two in some other part of the garden;— I see my steward coming this way:—I may want your assistance but too soon. Exit Araminta.
Enter STEWARD. Have you brought those papers I bad you look out?

SP.SPEAKER: STEWARD.
SP.P: Yes, Sir. But there is the gentleman within to wait upon your honour, concerning the estate you intended to purchase. It seems a mighty good bargain.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: I cannot speak to him now.

SP.SPEAKER: STEWARD.
SP.P: Your honour always used to be punctual.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Alas! Jonathan, I may be punctual again to∣morrow.—Give me the papers. Did Miss Beverley say she would come to me?

SP.SPEAKER: STEWARD.
SP.P: Immediately, Sir. But I wish your honour would consider, such bargains as these do not offer every day.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Heigh ho!

SP.SPEAKER: STEWARD.
SP.P: It joins so conveniently too to your honour's own estate, within a hedge as I may say.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Prithee don't plague me.

SP.SPEAKER: STEWARD.
SP.P: Nay, 'tis not my interest, but your honour's. Tho' that indeed I may call my interest, for I am sure I love your honour.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P:
I know thou dost, Jonathan, and I am too hasty,
—but leave me now.—If the gentleman will do me the favour of staying all night, I may satisfy him in the morning. My head and heart are too full now for any business which concerns my fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: STEWARD.
SP.P: Something goes very wrong with my poor mas∣ter. Some love nonsense or other I suppose— I wish all the women were in the bottom of the sea, for my part. Exit Steward.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: I thought it requisite, Sir John, as I heard you had something of importance to transact with my daughter, to wait upon you with her.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Was that necessary, madam?—I begged the fa∣vour of Miss Beverley's company only.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: But a mother, you know, Sir John, who has a tender concern for her child —

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Should shew it upon every occasion.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: I find, Sir John, there is some misunderstanding at present, which a woman of prudence and expe∣rience might be much better consulted upon, than a poor young thing, whose—

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Not at all, madam; Caelia has all the prudence I require, and our present conversation will soon be over.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Nay, Sir John, to be sure I am not afraid of trust∣ing my daughter alone with you. A man of your discretion will undoubtedly be guilty of no impro∣priety. But a third person sometimes, where the parties concerned are a little too much influenced by their passions, has occasioned very substantial, and very useful effects. I have known several in∣stances of it, in the course of my experience.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: This, madam, will not be one of them.—How teizing! Walking aside.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: I find, Sir John, that you are determined to have your own way, and therefore I shall shew you by my behaviour, that I know what good manners re∣quire, tho' I do not always meet with the same treatment from other people. Exit Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P: Now, Caelia, we are alone, and I have many excuses to make to you for the impassioned sallies of our late conversation; which I do most sincere∣ly.—Can you pardon them?

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: Alas! Sir, 'tis I who ought to intreat for pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P:
Not in the least, madam, I have no blame to cast upon you for any part of your conduct. Your youth and inexperience, joined to the goodness of your heart, are sufficient apologies for any shadow of indiscretion which might appear in your behavi∣our. I am afraid mine was not so irreproachable. However, Caelia, I shall endeavour to make you all the amends in my power; and to shew you that
it is your happiness, not my own, which is the ob∣ject of my anxiety.

Your father's will is but too clear in its inten∣tions. But the purity of his heart never meant to promote my felicity at the expence of yours. You are therefore, madam, entirely at liberty from this moment, to make your choice where you please. This paper will entitle you to that authority, and this will enable you to bestow your fortune where you bestow your hand.—Take them, my dear! —Why are you so disturbed?—Alas, Caelia, I see too plainly the cause of these emotions. You only wish the happy man to whom you have given your heart, loved you as I do!—

But I beg pardon; and will only add one cau∣tion, which my duty demands of me, as your guardian, your protector, and your father's friend. —You have been a witness of Modely's transacti∣ons with my sister. Have a care therefore, Caelia; be sure of his firm attachment before you let your own hurry you into a compliance. These papers give you up all power on my part; but as an ad∣viser, I shall be always ready to be consulted.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: My tears and my confusion have hitherto hin∣dered me from answering; not the invidious sug∣gestion which you have so cruelly charged me with. What friend, what lover have I, to engross my at∣tentions? I never had but one, and he has cast me off for ever.—O, Sir, give me the papers, and let me return them where my soul longs to place them.

SP.SPEAKER: SIR JOHN.
SP.P:
No, Caelia, to accept them again, would im∣peach the justice of my whole proceeding. It
would make it look like the mean artifice of a mercenary villain, who attempted to gain by stra∣tagem what his merits did not entitle him to.— I blush to think of it.—I have performed my office. Be mistress of yourself, and let me fly from a com∣bat to which I find myself unequal. Exit Sir John.

DIV2.STAGE: (CAELIA sits down, leaning her head upon her hand.)

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Hist! hist! he has just left her, and in a fine situation for my approaches.—If you are not yet satisfied, I will make up all differences with you another time.—Get into the arbour, and be a witness of my triumph. You shall see me, like another Caesar, Come, See—and Overcome.
SP.STAGE: (MODELY comes forward, walks two or three turns by her, bowing as he passes, without being taken notice of, then speaks.)
SP.P: If it is not an interruption, madam, when I find you thus alone —

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA
SP.P: I would chuse to be alone.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA
SP.P: In short, Mr. Modely, your behaviour to me of late is what I can by no means approve of. It is unbecoming your character as a man of honour, and would be a stain to the ingenuous modesty of my sex for me to suffer it.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P:
You surprize me, madam. Can the adoration of an humble love, the timid advances of a man
whom you beauty has undone, be such unpardonable offences?

DIV2.STAGE: (CAELIA looks with indignation at him, and is going off.)

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY
SP.STAGE: (catching hold of her, and falling upon his knees.)
SP.P: Nay, madam, you must not leave me!

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: Rise, Sir, or I am gone this moment.—I thought of flying from you, but my soul disdains it. —Know then, Sir, that I am mistress of myself, mistress of my fortune, and may bestow my hand wherever my heart directs it.

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: My angel! — Coming eagerly up to her.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: What do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: That you make the most sincere of lovers, the happiest of mankind. The addition of your for∣tune will add splendor to our felicity; and the frowns of disappointed love, only heighten our en∣joyments.

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: Oh thou vile one!—How does that cruel generous man who has rejected me, rise on the comparison!

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
SP.P: Rejected you?—Sir John Dorilant?

SP.SPEAKER: CAELIA.
SP.P: Yes, Mr. Modely, that triumph at least is yours. I have offered myself, and been refused. My hand and fortune equally disdained. But may perpetual happiness attend him, where'er his honest, honest heart shall fix!

SP.SPEAKER: MODELY.
